abstract: Paul Tough's article ''What if the Secret to Success Is Failure?'' received a tremendous response from readers when it appeared in the Education Issue last month, including 270 comments on our Web site and 40 percent of the magazine's page views.
snippet: Paul Tough's article ''What if the Secret to Success Is Failure?'' received a tremendous response from readers when it appeared in the Education Issue last month, including 270 comments on our Web site and 40 percent of the magazine's page views.
lead_paragraph: Paul Tough's article ''What if the Secret to Success Is Failure?'' received a tremendous response from readers when it appeared in the Education Issue last month, including 270 comments on our Web site and 40 percent of the magazine's page views. But we were very excited to see the article have a kind of second life over at The Learning Network, a New York Times blog for students and teachers. Our colleagues at The Learning Network used the article to kick off a new ''Reading Club,'' and there were 534 student comments on Tough's article. The Reading Club forum encourages discussion, and it was pretty exciting to see students thoughtfully debate questions about social class and character; parental influence and character; and the difference between struggle and failure. There was a lot of respectful disagreement, though the comments I read seemed to be nearly unanimous on one point: No report cards for character, please.

headline.main: Is Failure the Secret to Success? Student Edition
